prompt:
Patient: 68 M

completion:
NOTE_ID: note_032
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Al-Fayed

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
68-year-old male who presents with lung mass, multiple lung nodules, mediastinal/hilar lymphadenopathy, and LLL lobar atelectasis.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

PROCEDURE
Navigational Bronchoscopy (computer assisted) with Ion Robotic Bronchoscope (LUL and RML)
Radiology guidance for CT guided needle placement (Cios Spin)
3D rendering with interpretation and reporting (Ion Planning Station)
Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion
Fiducial marker placement
Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) of LUL and RML targets
Transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBBX) of LUL and RML targets
Transbronchial brushing and Mini-BAL
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) of LUL, RML, and LLL
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) for clot/mucus clearance
EBUS sampling 3 or more nodes (Stations 11L, 4L, 7)
Ultrasound Elastography (First and Additional Targets)
Destruction of tumor (Cryotherapy and APC) at LLL
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS)

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (LUL and RML), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Right Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Left Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of LLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the LLL segments (LB7/8 and LB6), causing complete obstruction. LB9-10 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical-Posterior Segment LB1/LB2, 7.4 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
LUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RML Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lateral Segment RB4, 2.3 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, iced saline, and topical epinephrine.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
LUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
RML BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11L, 4L, 7 (cytology for each)
LLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
68-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (RUL and LUL), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, iced saline, and topical epinephrine.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

RUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)

Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RLL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Anterior Segment LB3, 2.1 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RML)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RML segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB4 and RB5; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB4 and RB5):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB4 and RB5) remained 0% patent. RB6 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with application of cold saline and oxidized cellulose.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)

rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).

The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, iced saline, and topical epinephrine.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
RUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7 (cytology for each)
RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
73-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (LUL and RML), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Right Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Left Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of LLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the LLL segments (LB7/8 and LB6), causing complete obstruction. LB9-10 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical-Posterior Segment LB1/LB2, 7.4 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
LUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RML Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lateral Segment RB4, 2.3 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
LUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
RML BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11L, 4L, 7 (cytology for each)
LLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
79-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

prompt: Complex bronchoscopy with Modifier 22. Robot nav to RUL and LUL. EBUS staging. Endobronchial destruction of tumor at RLL. Multiple biopsies and BALs. Time extended due to complexity.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_032
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Rossi

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
82-year-old male who presents with lung mass, multiple lung nodules, mediastinal/hilar lymphadenopathy, and RLL lobar atelectasis.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

PROCEDURE
Navigational Bronchoscopy (computer assisted) with Ion Robotic Bronchoscope (RUL and LUL)
Radiology guidance for CT guided needle placement (Cios Spin)
3D rendering with interpretation and reporting (Ion Planning Station)
Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion
Fiducial marker placement
Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) of RUL and LUL targets
Transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBBX) of RUL and LUL targets
Transbronchial brushing and Mini-BAL
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) of RUL, LUL, and RLL
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) for clot/mucus clearance
EBUS sampling 3 or more nodes (Stations 2R, 4R, 7, 10R)
Ultrasound Elastography (First and Additional Targets)
Destruction of tumor (Cryotherapy and APC) at RLL
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS)

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (RUL and LUL), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Harken

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 2R, 4R, 7, 10R.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, cold saline, epinephrine 0.2mg, and APC.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
RUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 2R, 4R, 7, 10R (cytology for each)
RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
82-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)

Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with application of cold saline and oxidized cellulose.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
RUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11L, 4L, 7 (cytology for each)
RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

84-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (LUL and RML), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Right Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Left Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of LLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the LLL segments (LB7/8 and LB6), causing complete obstruction. LB9-10 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical-Posterior Segment LB1/LB2, 7.4 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
LUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RML Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lateral Segment RB4, 2.3 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
LUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
RML BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7 (cytology for each)
LLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
73-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

Radiology guidance for CT guided needle placement (Cios Spin)
3D rendering with interpretation and reporting (Ion Planning Station)
Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion

Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) of RUL and LUL targets
Transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBBX) of RUL and LUL targets
Transbronchial brushing and Mini-BAL

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (RUL and LUL), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 2R, 4R, 7, 10R.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, cold saline, epinephrine 0.2mg, and APC.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
RUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 2R, 4R, 7, 10R (cytology for each)
RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

62-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 7, 4R, 4L, 11L.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RLL segments (RB6 and RB10), causing complete obstruction. RB7-9 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical Segment RB1, 6.2 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lingula LB4, 1.8 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 7, 4R, 4L, 11L.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial tumor within multiple RLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB6 and RB10; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB6 and RB10):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB6 and RB10) remained 0% patent. RB7-9 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, cold saline, epinephrine 0.2mg, and APC.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical-Posterior Segment LB1/LB2, 7.4 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
LUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RML Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lateral Segment RB4, 2.3 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11Ri, 11Rs, 4R, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.

Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (RLL and LUL), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Harken

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Left Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Right Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of RML bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the RML segments (RB4 and RB5), causing complete obstruction. RB6 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RLL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Superior Segment RB6, 5.5 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
RLL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Anterior Segment LB3, 2.1 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
LUL BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (RML)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple RML segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at RB4 and RB5; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (RB4 and RB5):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (RB4 and RB5) remained 0% patent. RB6 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with application of cold saline and oxidized cellulose.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
RLL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
RLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LUL Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11L, 4L, 7 (cytology for each)
RML BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
73-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

prompt: Complex bronchoscopy with Modifier 22. Robot nav to LUL and RML. EBUS staging. Endobronchial destruction of tumor at LLL. Multiple biopsies and BALs. Time extended due to complexity.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_032
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Chen

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
73-year-old female who presents with lung mass, multiple lung nodules, mediastinal/hilar lymphadenopathy, and LLL lobar atelectasis.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field

PROCEDURE
Navigational Bronchoscopy (computer assisted) with Ion Robotic Bronchoscope (LUL and RML)
Radiology guidance for CT guided needle placement (Cios Spin)
3D rendering with interpretation and reporting (Ion Planning Station)
Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion
Fiducial marker placement
Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) of LUL and RML targets
Transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBBX) of LUL and RML targets
Transbronchial brushing and Mini-BAL
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) of LUL, RML, and LLL
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) for clot/mucus clearance
EBUS sampling 3 or more nodes (Stations 11L, 4L, 7)
Ultrasound Elastography (First and Additional Targets)
Destruction of tumor (Cryotherapy and APC) at LLL
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS)

MODIFIER 22 (INCREASED PROCEDURAL SERVICES)
This patient required Transbronchial Cryo biopsies at two different locations, Robotic Navigation to two different sites (LUL and RML), CT-guided needle placement at two locations, multiple Bronchoalveolar lavages in three different locations, Brushings at multiple locations, and Radial EBUS performed at multiple locations. The patient required endobronchial biopsies at two discrete locations and endobronchial destruction of tumor by method other than excision at two discrete locations. The patient required ultrasound elastography evaluation of discrete lymph node sites, with the images/interpretation used for intraprocedural decision-making. This resulted in >100% increased work due to increased intensity, time, technical difficulty, severity of patient's condition, and physical/mental effort required.

ATTENDING: Dr. Jones

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Linear EBUS; Radial EBUS; Ion Robotic Bronchoscope.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Moderate
COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
A timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. After the successful induction of anesthesia, anesthesia placed an ETT.
Ventilation Parameters: Mode: VCV; RR: 14; TV: 450; PEEP: 12; FiO2: 70%; Flow Rate: 10; Pmean: 17.

Initial Airway Inspection
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal with thin bloody secretions.
Right Lung: Bloody secretions and scattered mild blood clot burden within the airways. Normal anatomic branching to first subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor or active bleeding source identified.
Left Lung: Moderate blood secretions and large clot burden, including complete obstruction of LLL bronchus due to clot.

Following therapeutic aspiration, endobronchial tumor was noted protruding from the LLL segments (LB7/8 and LB6), causing complete obstruction. LB9-10 segments appeared patent after clot removal.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea and bilateral mainstems from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — LUL Mass
A CT-based navigation plan was loaded and partial registration was completed. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the planned target (Apical-Posterior Segment LB1/LB2, 7.4 cm lesion).
rEBUS: Concentric pattern with continuous margin and absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): A low dose spin was performed; 3D reconstruction and overlay confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 8 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Flow, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 10 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (6s freeze) (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Cytology).
Fiducial: One 0.8mm x 3mm soft tissue gold marker placed under fluoroscopy.
ROSE: TBNA showed atypical cells, large naked nuclei; cryo showed possible atypical histiocytes; not definitive for RCC.
LUL BAL: Performed with 40 cc saline, 15 cc return.

Robotic Navigational Bronchoscopy (Ion) — RML Nodule
Partial registration was repeated. The catheter was advanced to 0.5 cm from the target (Lateral Segment RB4, 2.3 cm).
rEBUS: Eccentric pattern with continuous margin.
Cone-Beam CT (Cios Spin): 3D reconstruction confirmed tool-in-lesion.

Sampling:
TBNA: 7 samples collected with 21G and 23G needles (Cytology, Cultures).
Cryobiopsy: 6 samples collected with 1.1 mm cryoprobe (Pathology).
Brushing: 1 sample (Cytology).
Mini-BAL: 10 cc instilled, 5 cc return (Micro/Cultures).
Fiducial: Attempted, but marker appeared to fall out and did not enter the nodule.
ROSE: Macrophages, lymphocytes, bronchial cells.
RML BAL: Performed with 60 cc saline, 60 cc return.

Post-biopsy fluoroscopy was negative for pneumothorax bilaterally.

EBUS Staging and Elastography
The EBUS scope was introduced. All lymph node stations were assessed; only those >=5 mm were sampled.
Lymph nodes sampled: Stations 11L, 4L, 7.
Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with suction, iced saline, and topical epinephrine.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

SPECIMENS
LUL Mass: TBNA (cytology, flow, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cytology)
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
RML Nodule: TBNA (cytology, cultures), TBCBx (pathology), Brushing (cytology), Mini-BAL (cultures)
RML BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
EBUS TBNA: Stations 11L, 4L, 7 (cytology for each)
LLL BAL: Cell count, micro, cytology
LLL Endobronchial Biopsy: Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN
73-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for lung mass biopsy, lung nodule biopsy, lymph node assessment, and endobronchial tumor destruction.
Obtain post-procedure CXR (ordered).
Inpatient primary team and IP consult team to follow up final results.
If discharged, follow up in IP clinic in 1-2 weeks.
If hemoptysis develops, recommend starting nebulized TXA.

Elastography showed mixed Type 1 (soft/benign) and Type 2 (mixed soft/stiff) patterns across stations.
ROSE for EBUS: Adequate lymphocytes and histiocytes present in all samples.

Endobronchial Tumor Management (LLL)
Endobronchial tumor within multiple LLL segmental airways was friable and bled easily.
Biopsy: Endobronchial cryobiopsy performed at LB7/8 and LB6; lesions successfully removed and sent for pathology.
ROSE: Atypical cells, large naked nuclei.

Tumor Destruction (LB7/8 and LB6):
Cryotherapy: 1.1mm probe used (8-12 sec) to debulk tumor.
APC: 1.5mm probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Effect 2) applied for coagulation/devitalization.

Results: Partial ablation achieved; hemostasis achieved (resolution of bleeding). However, airways (LB7/8 and LB6) remained 0% patent. LB9-10 airways were 100% patent after extraction of clot and nearby tumor.
Hemostasis: Nashville Grade 2 bleeding controlled with continuous suction and wedging of the scope.

Conclusion
Residual secretions were suctioned. No active bleeding was seen. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.
